results.title: Brush techniques
results.brief_description: This is the second of a series of films on water colour painting which have been made in collaboration with Eliot O’Hara; the companion film, the first in the series, is “Painting reflections in water”. In “Brush techniques”, O’Hara executes a water colour sketch in order to demonstrate how he communicates his impression of a landscape to whose who view his paintings.

results.title: Brush Creek bounces back
results.creator_credit: Stuart Finley and State of West Virginia, Dept of Commerce
results.brief_description: Illustrates how the Brush Creek Small Watershed Project converted the valley into an award winning example of good conservation practices. This enhanced land values, provided new recreation facilities and created new jobs.

results.title: Bruegel's people
results.creator_credit: Robert W Gutteridge and Vox Productions
results.brief_description: Presents the work of the Flemish painter Pieter Bruegel the Elder. Summarises the sources of the emotions, expressed on the faces of Bruegels people, pointing out the civil strife, tyranny, and religious repression prevalent in Flemish society of Bruegel’s time. Narrated by Raymond Wilcox.

results.title: Brown men and red sand
results.creator_credit: C Mountford and South Australian Government Tourist Bureau
results.brief_description: This film is part of the original silent film record of C.P. Mountford’s Central Australian journey with a group of desert First Nations people. From the original footage the two popular sound films, “Walkabout” and “Tjurunga”, were compiled. “Brown men and red sand” (if projected at silent speed) shows movement more naturally than in the sound films, where the movements look jerky (especially in the sequences dealing with ceremonies and dances).

results.title: Brown coal to briquettes
results.creator_credit: Frank Hurley and State Electricity Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description: Classroom film showing the manufacture of briquettes at Yallourn and Morwell Victoria. Includes demonstration by models of processes; operation of coal dredges at open cut; crushing and drying of coal; pressing of fine powder into briquettes; transport of finished product to other parts of Victoria.

results.title: Brown bears go fishing
results.brief_description: This film aims to stimulate interest in reading and to increase the vocabulary of primary pupils by using over prints and repetition in the narration. While reading and looking at storybooks, a group of children learn about the habits of polar bears and American black bears. Shows Alaskan brown bears swimming in a stream, catching and eating salmon, fighting over fish and teaching cubs how to swim.

results.title: Brotherhood of man
results.creator_credit: Robert Cannon, Stephen Bosustow and United Productions of America
results.brief_description: This film was made as a contribution to “Brotherhood Week” held in the USA in 1946, in which President Truman called on Americans to see that fair practices were the rule in both private and industrial life. The film is based on the pamphlet “Races of Mankind”, written by Dr.Ruth Benedict and Gene Weltfish, anthropologists of Columbia University USA, and published in 1943. “Brotherhood of man” explodes a number of commonly held fallacies which lead to racial discrimination and group persecution. It gives a clear scientific exposition of a number of basic biological and historical facts, which demonstrate the fundamental identity of humanity, stressing the need for tolerance and co-operation between all groups and races since human beings are always dependent on other human beings. It uses humor rather than drama to make its points. The soundtrack of this film was translated and re-recorded for use by the USA Occupation forces in Europe.

results.title: Bronze
results.creator_credit: Pierre Moretti, Francois Seguillon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film presents the conception and execution of a work of art - a monumental bronze work by Montreal sculptor Charles Daudelin, now standing outside the National Arts Centre in Ottawa. Shows the shaping of the model in its styrofoam stage with knife, saw and blowtorch. The film is without words, but with music to evoke the mood. Credits: Photography by Thomas Vamos and Michel Thomas-d’Hoste; edited by Yves Leduc; music by Maurice Blackburn and sound by Claude Delorme.

results.title: The Bronswick affair
results.creator_credit: Andre Leduc, Robert Awad, Rene Jodoin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A very funny yet deadly serious film, The Bronswick Affair, demonstrates the effectiveness of advertising in motivating people to buy products they don’t need. It entertains through the comic appeal of its characters and the baroque situations they fall prey to. It also lays bare some facts about the excesses of consumerism prompted by a steady flow of commercials. Nine awards including Chicago; New York; Yorkton; Columbus; Melbourne.

results.title: Brolga
results.brief_description: The life cycle of the brolga, Australia’s only red crane, also known as the native companion. Flocks gather in the early morning to feed on insects, rodents and herbage. About September the birds pair off for mating, after a strange courting dance, and raise two chicks, which soon learn to follow their parents around. At about four months they are big enough to fly and join the flock. The film includes a number of remarkable sequences, photographed in slow motion, recording brolgas in flight.
